intro: Lindernia minuta, commonly known as the dwarf lindernia, is a small herbaceous plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, hairy stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Lindernia minuta is often found in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to drought conditions. Its foliage is usually narrow and linear, with a bluish-green hue that adds visual interest to garden settings.
